clues.text: This president's home, the Hermitage, is located on Rachel's Lane
In 1873 Central University was renamed this for the "Commodore" who gave it a $1 million gift
This singer's museum near Nashville has a section featuring the Carter family
From 1943 to 1974, Ryman auditorium was the broadcast site of this radio program
Nashville's Parthenon has a 42-foot replica of this goddess
From the Old French for "crib", it's a representation of a Nativity scene
From Old English for "One that breaks faith", it's a male witch
This term for a little angel often depicted as a rosy-cheeked child comes from Hebrew
From Sanskrit meaning "Great Queen", it's the wife of a Majarajah
Our word "bog" probably came from this language; it helps if you think of peat bogs
Originally, the ell was a measurement from the fingertip to this
A candela is a measurement of the intensity of this
The boiling point of water at sea level is 212 on the Fahrenheit scale & this on the Celsius scale
Equivalent to 39.37 inches, its name comes from a Latin word meaning "measure"
The ancient Romans used this unit of weight, which they called a "libra"
"Paint Your..."
"Take the Money and..."
"The Asphalt..."
"My Stepmother is..."
"Tell Me That You Love Me..."
In the 5th C. BC Athens headed the Delian & this militaristic city, the Peloponnesian League
When the Roman Empire split in two in 395 A.D., Greece remained in the half called this
Mathematician & philosopher who discovered the intervals in an octave & probably played a mean triangle
The possession of Amazon Queen Hippolyta that is captured by Hercules
In the 4th century BC it was thought if this creature of Asklepios licked your eyes it might cure blindness
The name of these South American islands is Spanish for "land of fire"
Once a great whaling base, this island is Massachusetts' southeasternmost point
An orange-flavored liqueur is named for this island, the largest of the Netherlands Antilles
These two main islands of New Zealand are separated by the Cook Strait
Canada's St. John's Island was renamed this in 1799 in honor of the Duke of Kent
In 1890 William Kemmler became the first person executed in this shocking manner
In 1964 he was convicted of misappropriating $1.7 million in Teamster pension funds
Implicated in the Lincoln assassination, this doctor was sent to a prison in the Dry Tortugas
"Mad Bomber" George Metesky terrorized this city in the 1950s
This legendary highwayman was finally hanged as a horse thief at York in 1739
The German title of this Franz Werfel novel is called Das Lied von Bernadette
"The 42nd Parallel" by John Dos Passos depicts the U.S. on the eve of this war
Charlotte & Emily's sister who wrote "The Tenant of Wildfell Hall"
Russian who based the character Karmazinov in "The Possessed" on his rival, Ivan Turgenev
Aramis is the Bishop of Vannes in his novel "The Vicomte de Bragelonne"
Several states, including Virginia & Maryland, still ban most hunting on this day of the week
He was born in Burlington, New Jersey, not in Cooperstown, New York, which his father founded
Georgia's Stone Mountain sculpture depicts 3 men & 3 of these animals
The Sioux call this Wyoming national monument "The Bad God's Tower"
Nickname for a police van that may derive from the name of a woman who ran a seedy Boston boarding house
The myocardium muscle performs the main work of this organ
The brain stem connects the cerebrum with this part of the nervous system
A delicate membrane called the pleura covers each of these organs
The hypothalamus controls this "master gland" which in turn controls others
This largest part of the large intestine includes sections called the transverse & descending
This 1966 Truman Capote book combined fiction with facts to tell about 2 drifters who murdered a Kansas family
Thunderhead is the title horse in Mary O'Hara's follow-up to "My Friend" her
The old money & new money Long Island neighborhoods in this novel are East Egg & West Egg
In a post-Civil War novel by Allan Gurganus, the "Oldest Living" one of these women "Tells All"
Bullfights & heavy drinking are the order of the day in this 1926 novel with a title from Ecclesiastes

rounds.comments: (Alex: Quotes from Baby and Child Care by the celebrated doctor.)

clues.text: "The average baby gets his first" this "around 7 months" & 20 of them by age 2 1/2
"This item is helpful for colic and to prevent thumb-sucking" (& it does give parents some peace)
"The stump that's left" of this "withers and... drops off, usually in about a week"
About pregnancy, don't tell Junior about this animal; "Better not to... have him later decide" you lied
"Diphtheria, pertussis" & this "inoculations... should be started very early"

rounds.text: In her 1st Olympics, she finished last but later won 3 consecutive gold medals in figure skating
